title: Constraints & Generalized Coordinates Quiz
description: Test your understanding of holonomic and non-holonomic constraints, examples, generalized coordinates, DOF, virtual displacement, and generalized forces with both conceptual and numerical questions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a holonomic constraint?

options.text: Bead constrained to move on a fixed wire
options.explanation: The equation of the wire depends only on coordinates → holonomic.

options.text: No sideways slipping of a wheel

questions.question: A pendulum of length l has how many degrees of freedom (DOF)?

options.explanation: One angle θ completely specifies the pendulum’s configuration.

questions.question: Which of these are examples of non-holonomic constraints?

options.text: Knife edge constrained to move only forward
Particle constrained to move on a circle
The actual motion of the system
A hypothetical infinitesimal displacement consistent with constraints at fixed time
options.explanation: It is not real motion but a conceptual displacement for deriving equations.

questions.question: Generalized force corresponding to a generalized coordinate is defined through:

options.explanation: Generalized forces are defined so δW = Σ Qj δqj.

questions.question: A particle in 3D space (3 DOF) is constrained to a sphere x²+y²+z²=R². What is its new DOF?

options.explanation: One holonomic constraint reduces DOF from 3 to 2 (θ, φ).

questions.question: A rigid body in free space has 6 DOF. If it is hinged at one point, how many DOF remain?

options.explanation: Hinge removes 3 translational DOF, leaving 3 rotational DOF.

questions.question: A double pendulum (two masses with rigid rods) has how many DOF?

options.explanation: Each pendulum has one independent angle → 2 DOF in total.

questions.question: Which coordinate system best describes a simple pendulum?

options.explanation: One generalized coordinate θ is enough to describe motion.

options.text: Generalized coordinates can be angles, lengths, or any independent parameters
Holonomic constraints are expressible as coordinate equations
Non-holonomic constraints can always be converted into holonomic
